description.narrative: Implementation of eight full-fledged Country Outputs in Mauritania, Malawai, Mozambique, Rwanda, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Lao Peoples Democratic Republic, Nepal in support of PEA

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
1.1 Number of planning frameworks, legislation and regulations that integrate the poverty-environment nexus (per country) 1.2 Policy positions(s) on poverty-environment issues formulated by non-government actors 1.3 Number of government-led inter-sectoral coordination mechanisms that promote coherence of planning, frameworks, legislation and regulations 1.4 Number of countries where environmental/social/economic data are collected, analysed and reported applying a poverty-environment nexus perspective through national development and SDG monitoring systems
2.1: Number of key budget policy documents (e.g. budget statements, economic surveys, budget call circulars) that reflect environmental sustainability and climate priorities for poverty eradication (per country) 2.2. Number of countries with increased annual and medium-term sector budget allocations (including national and sub-national levels) that reflect environmental sustainability and climate for poverty eradication 2.3: Number of countries with fiscal instruments (tax, incentives, user fees, etc.) adopted in policies and regulations that prioritise quality investments 2.4: Number of guidelines and tools to manage private sector investment decisions that facilitate or prioritize quality investments

comment.narrative: • Number of planning frameworks, legislation and regulations that integrate the poverty-environment nexus (per country). Target: 31 • Policy position(s) on poverty-environment issues formulated by non-government actors. Target: 4 • Number of government-led inter-sectoral coordination mechanisms that promote coherence of planning, frameworks, legislation and regulations. Target:14 • Number of countries where environmental/social/economic data are collected, analyzed and reported applying a poverty-environment nexus perspective through national development and SDG monitoring systems. Target: 3 • Number of key budget policy documents (e.g. budget statements, economic surveys, budget call circulars) that reflect environmental sustainability and climate priorities for poverty eradication (per country) Target:5 • Number of countries with fiscal instruments (tax, incentives, user fees, etc.) adopted in policies and regulations that prioritize quality investments Target: 2 • Number of countries with fiscal instruments (tax, incentives, user fees, etc.) adopted in policies and regulations that prioritize quality investments. Target: 1 • Number of guidelines and tools to manage private sector investment decisions that facilitate or prioritize quality investments. Target: 8

Lao PDR: • 1 communication material on the CSR concept produced and published; • 6 investment profiles that address green growth, and dimension of quality project identified; • 1 pre-screening for quality used by government agencies to assess and regulate concessions and PIP projects; • 1 knowledge exchange event/product developed through study visits or South-South cooperation to share Lao PDR’s experience on the development and application of PEI or Poverty-Environment Action tools for quality investment promotion and management.
Malawi: • 2 new District Development Plans incorporate and implement national environment and natural resource management targets • 2 new sectors apply existing poverty-environment mainstreaming tools (GEDM, PSIP and SEP) in their budgeting and planning • 2 government coordination mechanisms (one at national and one at district level) apply an integrated approach to gender, natural resource sustainability and agricultural productivity • 2 systems developed to monitor multi-dimensional poverty-environment sustainability indicators
Mauritania: • 1 regional action plan incorporates poverty-environment (including gender and climate) dimensions • 1 sector policy includes poverty-environment, gender and climate dimensions • At least 1 poverty-environment indicator is included in the M&E system of the national development plan and is effectively reported against
Mozambique •  1 poverty-environment mainstreaming tool is used in the new planning and budget system (SPO) •  2 new budget management units (sectors or provinces) use environment and climate budget codes •  The 2019 budget for citizens includes an analysis of environmental and climate budget allocations • 0.63% of the annual budget is allocated for climate resilience and environmental sustainability (as compared to 0.45% baseline) •  An increase in the % of revenues from forestry and the extractive industries are canalized to communities
Myanmar:
• 50 Government staff (including parliamentarians) at Union and Subnational level trained on sustainability and resilience concepts (including on differential gender impacts), disaggregated by sex. High level seminar on developing a national integrated environmental financing framework and roadmap produced. • 1 knowledge product demonstrating potential for investment in environmental goods and services that can promote resilience and sustainability • 1 sector-based government plan developed incorporating resilience and sustainability criteria
Rwanda: •4 sectors (agriculture., urbanization, energy and industries) have mainstreamed poverty-environment objectives and included these in yearly plans and imihigo (imihigo is the Rwanda national report of natural resources) • 2 districts (Bugesera & Musanze) have locally-relevant poverty-environment evidence (including gender disaggregated) available to be used in future planning and programming • 2 districts (Bugesera & Musanze) have drafted cost effective P-E investment proposals • Budget circulars and environment and climate checklist revised for all 14 sectors based on the new National Strategy for Transformation • Baselines established for public expenditures on environment and climate change • Review on the combined values of private sector projects investing in sustainability undertaken
No 2019 Targets for Bangladesh and Nepal

Lao PDR • The draft Green Growth Criteria Guideline (GGCG) for selecting public investment developed as the guideline for the government agencies to apply green growth criteria in approving public investment projects, is now being advocated for use and in the National Green Growth Strategy. It is being lead by Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) to support the implementation of the national strategy and adapt to private investment selection. • Factsheet drafted, reviewed and revised to introduce the works of the project to government agencies that are implementing partners such as Ministry of Planning and Investment, Ministry of Natural Resource and Environment, Ministry of Industry of Commerce, Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism, and other related ministries. This factsheet will be disseminated to government officials including central and provincial authorities during the meetings, workshops and missions to different provinces. The final version is in printing procurement process. • Terms of Reference (TOR) to recruit a local consultant to develop promotion framework in tourism sector through reporting template, baseline study and other awareness raising mechanisms developed. The assignment also consists of the development of incubator guideline to support start-ups in tourism value chain which aims to strategically mobilize CSR funding from large concession projects to support these small business ideas. The recruitment had been delayed due to the lack of applicants applied for this position and has thus been re-advertised.
Malawi : • Socio-Economic Profiles (SEPs) of two districts: Salima and Chiradzulu districts reviewed to incorporate gender, Environment and Natural Resource Management (ENRM) and SDGs indicators with Poverty-Environment Action input. The SEPs are the basis for development of District Development Plans. • Project level coordination mechanism, in the form of a Project Coordination Team has been instituted. UNDP-FAO-UN Women project implementation arrangement have also been developed and adopted. • Poverty-Environment Initiative (PEI) reports on “Soil and Nutrient Loss in Malawi”, “Factors Driving the Gender Gap in Agriculture Productivity in Malawi”, and “Sustainable Management of the Environment and Natural Resources: Implications for Food Security, Livelihoods and Economic Development in Malawi” have been disseminated at a national level dissemination forum involving policy and technical representatives from Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs).
Mozambique • Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) concluded its first report on SDG implementation and is being prepared for publication. This report will be used as the basis for the National Voluntary Report that the country will present at the UN SDG high panel in 2020. Under the GHD component, Ministry of Land, Environment and Rural Development (MITADER0 have produced two main documents: (1) Appropriation of the SDGs that contribute to the environmental dimension, and (2) Planning guide for the SDGs under the responsibility of MITADER. These documents will allow MITADER to be able to monitor and report SDG indicators under its responsibility. • Dialogue has been initiated with government to include climate and environmental issues into the National Voluntary Report. • The SDG reference group that aims at assessing the capacity of the National Statistical Institute (INE) for data collection using SDG Indicators convened to review indicator status. One of the findings indicate the need to adapt the indicators into national planning system. Around 44 participants of different institutions participated. It was concluded that all 17 SDG fits into the national planning and policy. A total of 204 indicators (from the 232), are applicable, while 10 are not applicable and 18 are consider pending for further analyzing and adjustment to local context. Regarding availability, 67 global indicators were evaluated as currently available, 43 were easily viable, 89 were viable with great adjustment, and 5 indicators were evaluated as non-viable even with great adjustment. One of the main recommendations of this forum is the need for all representatives of the institutions present at the meeting to raise awareness on leadership (Directors and Ministers) the need to create conditions for the generation and availability of statistical indicators, broken down to lower levels (provincial or local, age, sex, disability, among others), which guarantees the international comparability recommended in the SDG report.
Myanmar • UNDP, the German Embassy, FFI, MCRB and Thant Myanmar (a local NGO) supported Environmental Conservation Department (ECD) to hold a workshop on managing plastic pollution in Myanmar. Involving approximately 60 people from government, private sector and civil society, the workshop included a roundtable discussion on Panel discussion on possible policy solutions to address plastic generation, consumption and disposal. This contributed to the development of the National Environmental Master Plan. • Considerable effort has been undertaken to support the ECD lead the mainstreaming of environmental indicators throughout the Myanmar Sustainable Development Plan (MSDP) and its associated National Indicator Framework. The project provided assistance for ECD to participate and advocate for appropriate indicators in the final round of inter-department consultations. The MSDP is the government’s overarching, long-term development plan, guiding all ministries and sectors. In addition to the dedicated section of the MSDP that addresses environmental conservation, the draft National Indicator Framework contains sustainability indicators throughout all strategies. • UNDP, the German Embassy, FFI, MCRB and Thant Myanmar (a local NGO) supported ECD to hold a workshop on managing plastic pollution in Myanmar. Involving approximately 60 people from government, private sector and civil society, the workshop included a roundtable discussion on Panel discussion on possible policy solutions to address plastic generation, consumption and disposal. This contributed to the development of the National Environmental Master Plan. • Initial research on successful examples of green businesses from the region has been finalized to be used as the basis for the folio and for promoting such investments in future years. The publication of the folio will be pursued as part of the work to promote investment in environmental goods and services.
Rwanda • Reviewed inclusion of ENR indicators, which form part of the environment and climate change checklist for the 2020 – 2021 Sectors and Districts’ annual action plans that were submitted to Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning (MINECOFIN) in preparation of new budget (2020-2021). The review indicates a slight increase in budget allocation on environment and climate change from 6.2% (2018/19) to 6.8% (2019/20). The assessment of the budget allocation was based on the checklist that was developed as a tool to support effective mainstreaming. Activities whose budget was assessed were those with matching indicators under the checklist. For this to be possible, 38 planners at the central level and 60 District Planners and environmentalists were trained on how to use Environment and climate change checklist while preparing their annual action plans. The training increased understanding of the planners which was evidence based by the quality of work plans incorporating environment and climate change elements. • preliminary discussion with Ministry of Gender and Family Promotion (MIGEPROF) held and agreed on possible collaboration during review of existing policies and strategies and development of ENR-Gender sensitive training module and training of relevant staff at ministerial and district level. • One local consultant was recruited to review existing policies and strategies, to identify any potential gaps in areas of ENR and Gender Mainstreaming, develop a training module and conduct a training of trainers targeting planners from ministerial and district levels who in turn will oversee implementation of this activity at their respective institutional level • Training of Sectors and District Planners on key ENR&CC indicators for fiscal year 2020/2021 was held at Lapalisse Nyamata/Bugesera from 26th to 30th August 2019. The training has influenced the planners to take into consideration ECC mainstreaming into their plans and ensure that they budgeted for.
Mauritania
Most of the work is on-going and depended on recruitment of consultants and procurement that has been delayed.

• Number of planning frameworks, legislation and regulations that integrate the poverty-environment nexus (per country). Target: 25 • Policy position(s) on poverty-environment issues formulated by non-government actors. Target: 2 • Number of government-led inter-sectoral coordination mechanisms that promote coherence of planning, frameworks, legislation and regulations. Target:10 • Number of countries where environmental/social/economic data are collected, analyzed and reported applying a poverty-environment nexus perspective through national development and SDG monitoring systems. Target: 0 • Number of key budget policy documents (e.g. budget statements, economic surveys, budget call circulars) that reflect environmental sustainability and climate priorities for poverty eradication (per country) Target: 4 • Number of countries with fiscal instruments (tax, incentives, user fees, etc.) adopted in policies and regulations that prioritize quality investments Target: 2 • Number of countries with fiscal instruments (tax, incentives, user fees, etc.) adopted in policies and regulations that prioritize quality investments. Target: 1 • Number of guidelines and tools to manage private sector investment decisions that facilitate or prioritize quality investments. Target: 12

• 15 planning frameworks, legislation and regulations that integrate the poverty-environment nexus (per country) developed. • 121 non-government actors supported to advocate/take action on poverty-environment issues. Note that the indicator description was changed to reflects new focus. • 4 government-led inter-sectoral coordination mechanisms promoted coherence of planning, frameworks, legislation and regulations. • 5 countries (Rwanda, Myanmar, Indonesia, Zimbabwe, Bangladesh) and 1 regional technical assistance initiative on Blue Economy collected, analyzed and reported data on environmental/social/economic applying a poverty-environment nexus perspective through national development and SDG monitoring systems. • 2 key budget policy documents (e.g. budget statements, economic surveys, budget call circulars) reflected environmental sustainability and climate priorities for poverty eradication. • 1 country (Indonesia) reflected an increase in annual and medium-term sector budget allocations (including national and sub-national levels) that reflect environmental sustainability and climate for poverty eradication. • 3 countries (South Africa, Indonesia, Nepal) adopted fiscal instruments in policies and regulations that prioritize quality investments (tax, incentives, user fees, etc.) • 28 guidelines and tools developed to manage private sector investment decisions that facilitate or prioritize quality investments.

- 2 Planning frameworks, legislation and regulations that integrate the poverty-environment nexus (per country). - 2 non-government actors supported to advocate/take action on poverty-environment issues. Note that the indicator description was changed to reflects new focus. - 6 government-led inter-sectoral coordination mechanisms that promote coherence of planning, frameworks, legislation and regulations. - 10 key budget policy documents (e.g. budget statements, economic surveys, budget call circulars) that reflect environmental sustainability and climate priorities for poverty eradication (per country) - 3 countries with fiscal instruments (tax, incentives, user fees, etc.) adopted in policies and regulations that prioritize quality investments. - 2 guidelines and tools to manage private sector investment decisions that facilitate or prioritize quality investments.
